questions.text: What is the technique of stimulating uterine contractions in a pregnant patient prior to the onset of spontaneous labour known as?
questions.solution:
The technique of stimulating uterine contractions prior to the onset of spontaneous labor is known as induction of labor.

It can be done irrespective of the rupture of membranes. 

Augmentation is the enhancement of spontaneous contractions that are considered inadequate because of failed cervical dilation and fetal descent.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for the induction of labor?

choices.text: History of lower transverse cesarean section in last three pregnancies

questions.solution:
Heart disease is currently not considered a contraindication for the induction of labor. Vaginal delivery is preferred in such patients.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G3P2 woman was admitted to the ward at 40 weeks of gestation for induction of labor. You were asked to calculate her Bishop's score. What should be the minimum score before performing this procedure?
questions.solution:
The minimum Bishop Score required before proceeding with induction of labour is 6.

A Bishop score >8 conveys a high likelihood of a successful induction. The latest guidelines state that a cut-off score of 6 can be used to choose between pharmacological and mechanical methods of induction.

This score is calculated based on the:

  • station of the fetal head
  • dilation of cervix
  • cervical length
  • position of cervix
  • consistency of the cervix.

This score is an important determinant of a successful induction.

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

questions.text: During rounds in the postnatal ward, you notice a patient's case sheet mentioning she had uterine tachysystole following labor induction. What is the criteria for this diagnosis?

choices.text: More than  5 contractions in a 5-min period
More than 5 contractions in a 10-min period
More than 10 contractions in a 5-min period
More than 10 contractions in a 10-min period

questions.solution:
Uterine tachysystole is defined as >5 contractions in a 10 min period and may occur in spontaneous or stimulated labor. It should always be qualified by the presence or absence of fetal heart rate abnormalities. Tachysystole interrupts maternal blood flow to the placenta during contractions and may lead to a reduction in fetal oxygenation. It is also associated with placental abruption.

It is caused by pharmacological agents used for cervical ripening and induction such as misoprostol (both oral and vaginal) and dinoprostone. Management includes stopping oxytocin infusion and terbutaline 0.25 mg SC.

questions.text: A primigravida was admitted to the labor room at 41 weeks of gestation for the induction of labor. What is the dose of misoprostol used for this procedure?
questions.solution:
Misoprostol (PGE1) is given as 25mcg 3-6 hourly vaginally or 25mcg 2 hourly orally for the induction of labor.

It is associated with the following side effects:

  • Uterine tachysystole
  • Meconium stained amniotic fluid
  • Uterine rupture

questions.text: Oxytocin is being given for augmentation of labour in a multigravida admitted to the labour room. Which of the following is not a mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: Receptor mediation through G-protein coupled receptors
Activation of voltage mediated Ca channel

questions.solution:
Competitive blocking of acetylcholine is not a mechanism of action of oxytocin.

Mechanism of action of oxytocin is as follows:

  • Receptor mediation through G protein-coupled receptors
  • Activation of voltage-gated Ca channel leading to calcium entry
  • Prostaglandin production by a positive feedback mechanism. This induces production of more prostaglandins and stronger contractions.

questions.text: In which of the following patients would you perform a controlled artificial rupture of membranes?

choices.text: G3P2 lady with absent fetal cardiac activity at 34 weeks of gestation
Multigravida with HIV at 36 weeks of gestation
G2P1 lady with AFI of 28 cm at 38 weeks of gestation
Term primigravida with red, tender, vesicular lesions on her vulva

questions.solution:
Controlled artificial rupture of membranes (ARM) is performed in a patient with amniotic fluid index (AFI) ≥ 25 cm. This points towards a diagnosis of polyhydramnios.

This is because if ARM is not done under controlled conditions in these patients, it can cause sudden decompression of the fetus. This can lead to abruption of placenta.

Contraindications to ARM:

  • Intrauterine fetal death
  • Active genital herpes infection
  • Maternal HIV-AIDS

questions.text: An obstetrician performs the following procedure for labor induction in a patient. Which of the following is false about the reflex elicited here?

choices.text: Occurs due to pressure at the external os of cervix
It is associated with increased level of PGF2α
Artificial rupture of membranes initiates this reflex
It is an example of positive feedback mechanism

questions.solution:
Stripping of membranes is being depicted in the image, which elicits the Ferguson reflex. It is also known as the fetal ejection reflex and is seen due to the pressure at the internal os of the cervix.

It is associated with an increase in blood levels of a prostaglandin F2α metabolite, also known as dinoprost. This is released due to mechanical stretching of the internal os. This enhances the uterine activity and causes release of more prostaglandins. It is an example of a positive feedback mechanism.

questions.text: All of the following are true about laminaria tents except:

choices.text: Leads to the release of endogenous prostaglandins

questions.solution:
The Bishop's score is rapidly improved by the use of laminaria tents.

It is a mechanical cervical dilator and acts by hygroscopic osmotic action, leading to slow dilatation of the cervix. The gentle dilatation by laminaria tents induces an endogenous synthesis of prostaglandins causing a softening of the cervix. This is useful in cervical ripening before induction of labour.

questions.text: A nursing assistant posted in the obstetric care unit was asked to plot a partograph to monitor the progress of labour. Where should she start marking the cervical dilatation?
questions.solution:
In a partograph, the first marking of cervical dilatation should be made on the left of the alert line. In a normal partograph, the plotting remains on the left of the alert line.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: You are monitoring the number, duration, and intensity of uterine contractions in a 34-year-old G2P1 woman with a term pregnancy. How long should they last for you to classify them as moderate?
questions.solution:
Moderate uterine contractions last for 20–40 s.

Weak contractions last for <20 s and strong contractions are >40 s.

During active labour, uterine contractions are 5 min apart for 1 hour, i.e., ≥ 12 contractions in 1 hour. This is accompanied by cervical dilatation of ≥3–5 cm.

questions.text: A G2P1 woman with polyhydramnios, presents to the clinic with respiratory distress at 38 weeks of gestation.  The obstetrician plans for induction of labor.  What is a safe method of induction in this patient?

choices.text: Abdominal amniocentesis followed by oxytocin drip

questions.solution:
Abdominal amniocentesis followed by oxytocin drip is a safe method for induction of labor in polyhydramnios.

Abdominal amniocentesis drains a good amount of liquor (amnioreduction), after which the oxytocin infusion can be started. This will minimize the sudden decompression and reduce the risk of placental separation, cord prolapse and change in lie of the fetus.

Although polyhydramnios does not constitute an absolute contraindication for the application of prostaglandins, these substances should be administered with caution. There is a marked increase in the incidence of postpartum hemorrhage and amniotic fluid embolism with their use. Hence, amnioreduction is a preferred mode of treatment in polyhydramnios.

questions.text: Given below is the partograph of a primigravida in labor. What should be the next step in managing her condition?

choices.text: Induction of labor by mechanical methods

questions.solution:
As the plotting on the above partograph has crossed the action line, the next step of management is Caesarean section.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: What is the half-life of oxytocin?
questions.solution: The half-life of oxytocin is approximately 3–5 min. Therefore, once oxytocin infusion is stopped, its concentration in plasma rapidly falls.

questions.text: During your OBG rotations, one of the senior residents asks you to induce labor in a primigravida admitted at 40 weeks of gestation. Identify the following device that you will use for the same.
questions.solution:
This is an image of a cervidil vaginal insert. It is used for cervical ripening and improves the Bishop's score.

It contains 10 mg of dinoprostone designed to release at a rate of approximately 0.3 mg/hr over 10-hours.

questions.text: According to the WHO Labour Care Guidelines, documentation of labour progress begins at a cervical dilatation of -
questions.solution:
According to the WHO Labour Care Guidelines, documentation of labour progress begins at a cervical dilatation of 5cm. 

WHO Labour Care Guidelines:

  • Time axis - examination findings are plotted every one hour 
  • Alert column- has values which if reached indicates the need for urgent medical intervention
  • Active first stage - findings are plotted every hour upto 12 hours. If the first stage continues, a new sheet is used.
  • Second stage - plotted every hour upto 3 hours

1) Section 1: Preliminary information

Name, parity, labour onset, active labour diagnosis (date), ruptured membranes (date&time), risk factors

2) Section 2: Supportive care

  • Companionship  
  • Pain relief 
  • Oral fluid 
  • Posture 

3) Section 3: Baby

  • Baseline FHR
  • FHR deceleration
  • Amniotic fluid
  • Fetal position
  • Caput
  • Moulding

4) Section 4: Vitals 

Pulse, SBP, DBP, temperature, and urine for proteins are recorded every 4 hours

5) Section 5: Labour progress

  • Count the number of uterine contractions over a 10-minute period. 
  • Assess the duration of contractions
  • Cervical dilatation: starts at 5 cm and is plotted as X; it is assessed every hour. For example - if the cervical dilatation remains at 5cm for ≥ 6hrs, it indicates the need for urgent intervention. Similarly, the cut-offs for - 6cm is ≥ 5hrs; 7cm is ≥ 3hrs; 8cm is ≥ 2.5hrs; 9cm is ≥ 2 hrs
  • Descent - plotted as O

6) Section 6: Medication

  • Oxytocin 
  • Medicine 
  • IV fluids

7) Section 7: Shared decision making

  • Assessment
  • Plan

*Fetal position, vitals of the mother and cervical dilatation can be assessed at 4 hourly if the labour is progressing adequately

*If birth is not completed by 3 hours from the start of the active second stage in nulliparous and 2 hours in multiparous women, intervention is needed

questions.text:
Which of the following modifications have been made in the WHO Labour care guidelines as compared to the modified partograph
  1. Monitoring of the second stage of labour
  2. Documentation of labour progression at regular intervals of 1 hour
  3. Record of strength, duration, and frequency of uterine contractions
  4. Record of labour companionship, posture, and oral fluid intake
  5. Initiation of documentation of labour progression at 5 cm cervical dilatation
questions.solution:
WHO modified partograph WHO Labour Care Guide
Documentation of labour progression begins at 4 cm of cervical dilatation. Documentation of labour progression begins at 5 cm of cervical dilatation.
Fixed 1 cm/hour ‘alert’ and ‘action’ lines Time-based cut-offs for each centimeter of cervical dilatation to guide the obstetrician to take action. For example, at 5 cm of cervical dilatation, if there is no progress >6 hours, action needs to be taken.
Monitoring of labour is restricted to the first stage only. Monitoring of second stage of labour is included
No section on supportive care interventions Addition of a section on supportive care of the mother- labour companionship, pain relief, oral fluid intake and posture
Documentation of strength, duration, and frequency of uterine contractions Documentation of only the duration and frequency of uterine contractions
